format: A data frame containing 4,870 observations on 27 variables.

parameters.requirements: factor. Does the ad mention some requirement for the job?
parameters.college: factor. Does the applicant have a college degree or more?
parameters.email: factor. Was the e-mail address on the applicant's resume?
parameters.ethnicity:
factor indicating ethnicity (i.e., Caucasian-sounding
vs. African-American sounding first name).
parameters.military: factor. Does the applicant have military experience?
parameters.minimum: factor indicating minimum experience requirement of the employer.
parameters.reqcomp: factor. Does the ad mention some computer skills requirement?
parameters.jobs: number of jobs listed on resume.
parameters.experience: number of years of work experience on the resume.
parameters.special: factor. Does the resume mention some special skills?
parameters.call: factor. Was the applicant called back?
parameters.computer: factor. Does the resume mention some computer skills?
parameters.reqorg: factor. Does the ad mention some organizational skills requirement?
parameters.city: factor indicating city: Boston or Chicago.
parameters.volunteer: factor. Did the resume mention some volunteering experience?
parameters.industry: factor indicating type of employer industry.
parameters.reqcomm: factor. Does the ad mention some communication skills requirement?
parameters.reqexp: factor. Does the ad mention some experience requirement?
parameters.reqeduc: factor. Does the ad mention some educational requirement?
parameters.holes: factor. Does the resume have some employment holes?
parameters.wanted: factor indicating type of position wanted by employer.
parameters.honors: factor. Did the resume mention some honors?
parameters.name: factor indicating applicant's first name.
parameters.school: factor. Does the resume mention some work experience while at school?
parameters.equal: factor. Is the employer EOE (equal opportunity employment)?

reference:
Cross-section data about resume, call-back and employer information for 4,870 fictitious
resumes sent in response to employment advertisements in Chicago and Boston in 2001, 
in a randomized controlled experiment conducted by Bertrand and Mullainathan (2004).
The resumes contained information concerning the ethnicity of the applicant.
Because ethnicity is not typically included on a resume, resumes were differentiated on
the basis of so-called “Caucasian sounding names” (such as Emily Walsh or Gregory Baker)
and “African American sounding names” (such as Lakisha Washington or Jamal Jones).
A large collection of fictitious resumes were created and the pre-supposed
ethnicity (based on the sound of the name) was randomly assigned to each resume.
These resumes were sent to prospective employers to see which resumes generated a phone call
from the prospective employer.
title: Are Emily and Greg More Employable Than Lakisha and Jamal?
description:
Description
Cross-section data about resume, call-back and employer information for 4,870 fictitious
resumes.
